ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Definitely recommended. Work is not little, but it is so enjoyable that it will not seem like a burden.

TAKE THIS COURSE. I don't care if you're not a lit or an Italian student, just take it. It will be one of your favorite courses at Yale. Why?- You learn a lot about really influential literature.- Your professor will be amazing. Awesome. Inspiring.- You will enjoy your assignmentsa few interesting papers, a Symposium styled speech, and a sonnet!- You will eat heart-shaped pizza and homemade tiramisu. Yum.
YES, because you will learn tons and you will have lots of fun!

Yes- it's a fun class, pretty laid back. The assignments are not hard but you still learn a lot from them. The papers forced me to reflect on everything I read, and it was great that I got to pick something that actually interested me. Writing the speech on love and the sonnet was fun, and it also challenged me to do something different that I hadn't done before.

This was a perfect senior year class for me. A survey of really interesting literature that, let's be honest, I was never going to read on my own, interspersed with creative work and genuine debate about love. A lecture that was small enough for class discussion but large enough to remain a lecture and justify having smaller sections, including one in Italian. A class that conducts a Symposium as part of its requirements. Everything was wonderful. Bravissimo.
